name: Moderator Gina
comment info:
Thanks to all the students who responded.   Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received:  ''Current" Issues with River Water Consumption" by Abigail of Colorado;  “The Colorado River Is Shrinking.  Why Might That Be? by Lincoln, Caleb, and Nico of Eaglecrest High School in Aurora, Colorado;   “Billion Gallons Gone Per Year: Livestock Is Drinking Dry the Colorado River“ by Carlos of Perth Amboy High School in New Jersey; “Is the Colorado River Sustainable?” by Elias of Andover High School in Massachusetts; “Dwindle N' Drain: Main Causes of the Depleting Colorado River” by Harnoor of Valley Stream, New York; and ''Waning Water in the West'' by Noa of Valley Stream North High School in New York.
 
Please return on Friday when we will reveal the free link to the article that includes this graph.  Also in the Reveal are a summary of the topic, additional questions, shout outs for some of the best headlines for the graph and Stat Nuggets -- definitions of words that relate to the graph and where you can find them in the graph.
 
The next graph will be released by Friday, December 1 and live-moderated on Wednesday, December 6.  The topic – teens and social media.
 
Signing off – Sharon Hessney from Boston, who is rethinking how much meat and ice cream she eats, and Gina Lee from Fairfax, Virginia, who is redefining her food story, one flexitarian step at a time.

name: Shreyan Jung
comment info:
This graph uses a visual depiction of a blue "river" splitting into various "tributaries" to represent the amount of actual water from the Colorado river that is consumed for each labeled purpose. The width of each "tributary" is proportional to the volume of water used for that purpose.

We wonder why there is a narrow strip that splits off of the livestock branch, appearing as if it would merge with the "other crops" branch, but later rejoins the livestock branch. Although it might simply be a visual artifact, we nevertheless noticed that the livestock and other crops branches are conceptually linked in several ways. For example, much of the water associated with raising livestock comes from irrigation of feed crops: we wonder whether this component was included in the livestock section or the "other crops" section, as corn is widely used for both human and livestock consumption. Corn is particularly relevant to my community, as it is one of the principal crops grown in Champaign County (along with soybeans).

"A Tribute to the Tributaries of Water Consumption"

replies.comment info:
Hi @Shreyan Jung,

It's great to hear you were able to connect it to the crops grown in your area! You are right that much of the water associated with raising livestock comes from irrigation of feed crops - this was indeed included in the "livestock" section.

What are the sources of water used to grow corn in Champaign County?

name: Isabella P. AOSE
comment info:
This graph demonstrates where the 1.9 trillion gallons of water per year taken from the Colorado River are distributed. It shows that 56% goes to livestock, 24% goes to other crops (cotton, wheat, corn, grain, barley, etc.), and 21%  goes to everything else (residential, commercial industrial, and thermoelectric power).  The Colorado River is shrinking rapidly. If it dries out, it would cause a catastrophe in the West. By analyzing this graph, we can see how to reduce our use of the water from the Colorado River.  The caption says that the Colorado River provides water for over 40 million people. I wonder in which category this statistic is factored into the graph. I assume that this would be included in either commercial or residential use. These two categories take up a tiny percentage of the Colorado River water each year. While we can attempt to reduce our daily intake of water, the larger consumers of water must be addressed first. Reducing our water use on animals and plants will make a bigger difference. I notice that over half of the water is devoted to livestock. We need to find ways to make this water use more sustainable. We could install more desalinization plants in the US to try and compensate for the lack of fresh water we have left. This could help reduce the use of water for livestock and crops as they could live off of desalinated freshwater. The shrinking rates of fresh water will become an increasingly prominent problem.
“Colorado River to Colorado Creek”

This graph shows how many gallons of water various categories consume from the Colorado River. Millions of people and animals would need water, leading them to consume from another water source with a population that already relies on it, would this cause another recession in water supply?
This is relatable because, I live in one of the most highly populated areas of America. To me, if this occurred in the West where it is less populated, what is to stop that from happening to us? In New Jersey, water is usually taken from neighboring states in order to provide for us which is astounding since we have one water source providing many states. If the population increases so drastically and droughts occur much more often now, what is to stop this from occurring in the East, too?
